subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Hazard Recognition and Risk Assessment
headline: Learn why hazard recognition and risk assessment are so important in today's workplace with this free online course.
description: This free online health and safety course will teach you how to recognize hazards and write appropriate risk assessments, and how to use other related health and safety tools. You will walk away from the course looking at your workplace with a different perspective. Hazard recognition and risk assessment are essential skills in any workplace. In this course, you'll learn everything you need to know about essential health and safety procedures.
courseDescription:
Hazard recognition and risk assessment are core competencies in safety and they require a tremendous amount of thought, specific knowledge regarding the type of work and its processes, and the ability to foresee what might happen next.

This course is an introduction to the tools needed to successfully complete a risk assessment. You will study different examples of risk assessments, processes, and examples in order to learn from the information gathering process. You will also learn about writing a risk assessment and how to include others in the process. The course also covers how to determine a risk level for the hazard and probability combination, how to create a hazard log, and what the hierarchy of controls involves. Other topics covered in the course include Job Safety Analysis (JSA), Safety Checklists and Job Hazard Alerts.

This course will be of great interest to learners who are part of the safety management system at their company, whether it is their full-time work or part of their responsibilities. Everyone is responsible for safety so everyone can benefit from this short course. Start this free online course now and gain valuable new skills in the areas of hazard recognition and risk assessment.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • On successful completion of this module, students will be able to:
    • Define hazard 
    • Define risk
    • Define severity
    • Explain why unsafe acts should be avoided
    • Describe why accidents can happen to anyone
    • List types of unsafe acts
    • Look at situations in their lives from a 'what could happen next' perspective
    • Explain why it is important to look at things from the perspective of 'what could happen next
    • Explain why it is important to involve everyone in the writing of Risk Assessments
    • Identify potentially hazardous situations
    • Describe why it important to control risk

  • Welcome to this Hazard Identification & Risk Assessment Course

  • Congratulations! You have taken the most important step in enhancing your knowledge of safety by taking this course.

    In this course, we will review the core competency of writing a risk assessment and other associated documents - a very challenging task to complete.

    Writing a risk assessment requires, among other things:

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • Thorough thought
    • Specific knowledge of the work processes, and
    • The ability to foresee what might happen next
  • We will help you with these skills throughout the course. By the end of the course, you will feel accomplished and ready to take on nearly any risk assessment writing task.

    Good luck with the course! Now for a few quick questions to get you thinking about recognizing hazards.

  • Let's Think Differently and Safer!

  • When you stand up from the desk you are at right now or walk around with your mobile device start thinking about what could happen if you are not aware of your surroundings. If the door in front of you opens towards you, what would happen if someone opened it quickly and with much force? Would you be injured?

    Hazard Identification and Risk Assessment is like playing chess. We need to constantly think about different directions life can take us, in the short term and long term. We need to think about what could happen next.

    Are you ready to think differently and safer? 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • It is important to think about the hazards at home and work and how to control them because we want to stay safe.

    Then let's look at two quick questions to get our minds thinking about what could happen next.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are the following:
    • Hazard is a potential source of harm.
    • Risk is the combination of probability of harm and severity of the potential harm.
    • Severity is the level of harm that will affect a person or persons.
    • It is every person's right to work in a safe environment.
    • Accidents can happen to anyone.
    • Avoid unsafe acts.
    • Unsafe acts which are not reviewed can lead to accidents, injuries and even death.
    • You should apply the lessons from our and our colleagues' experiences to future situations.
    • Signs of hazards and risks are all around us.
    • You can anticipate accidents and avoid them.
    • You must involve everyone in identifying the hazards and risks.
    • You must control the hazards and risks to avoid accidents.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are the following:
    • Hazard is a potential source of harm.
    • Risk is the combination of probability of harm and severity of the potential harm.
    • Severity is the level of harm that will affect a person or persons.
    • It is every person's right to work in a safe environment.
    • Accidents can happen to anyone.
    • Avoid unsafe acts.
    • Unsafe acts which are not reviewed can lead to accidents, injuries and even death.
    • You should apply the lessons from our and our colleagues' experiences to future situations.
    • Signs of hazards and risks are all around us.
    • You can anticipate accidents and avoid them.
    • You must involve everyone in identifying the hazards and risks.
    • You must control the hazards and risks to avoid accidents.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • On successful completion of this module, students will be able to:
    • List different ways of assessing risks
    • Describe different types of risk assessments
    • Explain the purpose and use of different types of risk assessments
    • Explain why digitizing safety forms is helpful
    • Describe the thought process of writing the different types safety forms
    • Describe the steps in writing a Risk Assessment Chart
    • Explain what needs to go into the Risk Assessment Chart
    • Be able to identify sources of risk for inclusion in the Risk Assessment Chart
    • Know how to choose the severity and likelihood of a safety incident
    • List the hierarchy of hazard controls
    • Consider appropriate controls for the identified risks

  • Learning Outcomes

  • On successful completion of this module, students will be able to:
    • List different ways of assessing risks
    • Describe different types of risk assessments
    • Explain the purpose and use of different types of risk assessments
    • Explain why digitizing safety forms is helpful
    • Describe the thought process of writing the different types safety forms
    • Describe the steps in writing a Risk Assessment Chart
    • Explain what needs to go into the Risk Assessment Chart
    • Be able to identify sources of risk for inclusion in the Risk Assessment Chart
    • Know how to choose the severity and likelihood of a safety incident
    • List the hierarchy of hazard controls
    • Consider appropriate controls for the identified risks

  • Risk Assessments - An Introduction

  • Select an Image from the Gallery


  • Now that we have found ways to think differently about how we go about our daily lives we will now delve into how to apply this thinking to the workplace where there are many different types of risks. We will not cover all the risks but provide you with a methodology of assessing the hazards and their potential risks and help direct you to find solutions to them.

  • Among the different ways of assessing risks include: 
    • Risk Assessment Matrix
    • Job Hazard Alert
    • Job Hazard/Safety Assessment
    • Hazard Tracking Log
    • Safety Inspection Checklist
    • and other factors

  • Risk Assessment Chart

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The Risk Assessment Chart is a formal and in depth method of reviewing the risks associated with the work to be implemented. It follows the steps of the work and reviews their hazards and associated risks. 

    The document can often be a 10 pages or longer which is preceded by a number of pages describing the work steps. It is a long and involved process. We outline here how fill in one row of the risk assessment chart using our basic example of changing a light bulb for you to fill in more rows at your workplace with the specific works unique to your workplace.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are the following:
    • Apply the 'thinking differently' approach to risk assessment writing.
    • Risk Assessment Matrix calculates the risk level and uses the results of the Risk Assessment Matrix.
    • Job Hazard Alerts inform all employees of the hazard and its mitigation.
    • Job Hazard/Safety Assessment helps to quickly assesses a situation before starting to work.
    • Hazard Tracking Log lists all the known hazards and is continuously updated.
    • Safety Inspection Checklists helps with reviewing the safety measures of routine activities.
    • When creating safety forms one must think about what the person filling it in needs to know.
    • The Risk Assessment Chart is comprised of eight main areas (columns).
    • The hierarchy of Hazard Controls are: Elimination, Substitution, Engineering, Administrative and Personal Protective Equipment (the last type of control to implement).
    • When workers implement the controls it is most effective.
    • There is no correct answer when choosing the severity level and likelihood. It is according to one's experience.
    • The residual risk should be lower than the initial risk as controls have been implemented.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are the following:
    • Apply the 'thinking differently' approach to risk assessment writing.
    • Risk Assessment Matrix calculates the risk level and uses the results of the Risk Assessment Matrix.
    • Job Hazard Alerts inform all employees of the hazard and its mitigation.
    • Job Hazard/Safety Assessment helps to quickly assesses a situation before starting to work.
    • Hazard Tracking Log lists all the known hazards and is continuously updated.
    • Safety Inspection Checklists helps with reviewing the safety measures of routine activities.
    • When creating safety forms one must think about what the person filling it in needs to know.
    • The Risk Assessment Chart is comprised of eight main areas (columns).
    • The hierarchy of Hazard Controls are: Elimination, Substitution, Engineering, Administrative and Personal Protective Equipment (the last type of control to implement).
    • When workers implement the controls it is most effective.
    • There is no correct answer when choosing the severity level and likelihood. It is according to one's experience.
    • The residual risk should be lower than the initial risk as controls have been implemented.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • On successful completion of this module, students will be able to:
    • List and explain each of the topics to be covered in a Job Safety Analysis
    • Identify the importance of involving everyone in the completing of the JSA through having them sign the form.
    • Describe the importance of taking the JSA seriously
    • List the parts of a Job Hazard Alert (JHA) Form and how to use a JHA
    • Explain how to publicize the JHA in your organization
    • Describe what is a Safety Alert
    • Define the use of a safety checklist and list the parts of a safety checklist
    • Define Safety Data Sheets (SDS)
    • Define what is a Hazard Log and explain that each facility is unique in its hazards
    • Explain that a Hazard Log is continuously updated
    • Internalize that everyone is responsible to report new hazards
    • List the parts of a Hazard Log
    • Hazard Logs are designed to be analyzed and yield trends in safety at the facility

    • Hazard Logs are designed to be analyzed and yield trends in safety at the facility

  • The JSA - Job Safety Analysis

  • The Job Safety/Hazard Analysis (JSA) is a form that work parties fill out before starting to do their daily work. It helps ask them the questions needed to make them think about to complete their daily work without injury. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The Job Safety/Hazard Analysis list of topics include:
    Date - This way we know when the JSA was filled in relative to other new hazards which have come up onsite.

    Job Name - What job is being done?

    Job Location - Where is the job being done? This often has implications on what other work is being done around it which could affect the work party or the work party's work can affect other teams.

    Task Number - sometimes in large projects tasks are given numbers to make it easier to track the tasks.
    Person Doing the Assessment - It is best if the whole work party and the safety manager are engaged in writing the JSA.

    Task Description - What work will be done?

  • Job Hazard Alert Form

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • A Job Hazard Alert Form is a formal way of submitting notice of a hazard that was discovered. All staff can submit the form to their manager. 
  • Topics covered in a typical Job Hazard Alert form include:
    • Date
    • Department
    • Location
    • Description of the Hazard
    • Manager/Supervisor's actions
    • Root Cause(s) for the Hazard
    • Control(s) set in place
    • Reviewed by
    • Date Corrected

  • Safety Checklists

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The safety checklist is used for routine activities to check off a standard list of items to be verified. A safety checklist can be generated for any type of work. 

    Checklists can be in the form of yes/no or adequate/not adequate/needs immediate attention and with room for comments.

    While a safety checklist can be written for nearly anything. They have some commonalities including:
    • Text is short
    • Usually one page
    • Answers are yes/no or a short line is provided for a short answer
    • Contains images to guide the person filling in the checklist

  • What is a Hazard Tracking Log?

  • The Hazard Tracking Log is a list of hazards in a facility. It is list that is continuously updated when new hazards are observed, when new equipment is installed in the facility and when modifications to existing equipment and processes occur.

    Each facility has its own set of hazards. Some common ones include: Chemical, electrical, steam and others. Some Hazards do not change over time and some can be eliminated or reduced.

    All staff are responsible to report new hazards that they observe. Normally, staff report to their manager or the facility safety manager and the safety manager updates the hazard log. Reporting is done verbally or in writing. Some facilities use the Job Hazard Alert form to report on new hazard. The Job Hazard Alert form is described in another section of this course.

    In the next pages we will see what a generic hazard tracking log looks like.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The hazard tracking log should be considered a 'living' document, meaning that it will continuously updated.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are the following:
    • The JSA is an important form in the documentation of safety onsite.
    • The JSA is comprised of at least the following fields; Date, Job Name, Location, Task Number, Name of the Person Filling in the the Assessment, Task Description, Hazard Type, Hazard Description, Consequence, Hazard Controls, Rational or Comment, Final Disposition, Signatures of all involved, Date
    • Each field is important as it helps document the history of the Job.
    • The JSA is part of the legal documentation of safety which may be reviewed in the event of an accident.
    • Job Hazard Alert Forms are comprised of at least the following; Date, Department, Location, Description of the Hazard, Manager/Supervisor's actions, Root Cause(s) for the Hazard, Control(s) set in place, Reviewed by, Date Corrected. Publicizing the JHA is a very important part of the JHA process.
    • Safety Checklists contain at least the following topics; Location, Foreman/supervisor's name, Inspector's name, Equipment name, Last date of maintenance, Mileage and are used for routine activities
    • Hazard Logs list all known hazards in the facility and are continuously updated and help track trends
    • Each facility has its own unique set of hazards
    • Hazard Logs are comprised of at least the following: Hazard Number, Description, Reported by, Date reported, Corrected by, Responsibility, Date Corrected

    • Job Hazard Alert Forms are comprised of at least the following; Date, Department, Location, Description of the Hazard, Manager/Supervisor's actions, Root Cause(s) for the Hazard, Control(s) set in place, Reviewed by, Date Corrected.     • Hazard Logs list all known hazards in the facility and are continuously updated and help track trends

  • Learning Outcomes

  • On successful completion of this module, students will be able to:
    • Describe how smartphones can be used in the construction industry
    • List what makes a good construction smartphone app
    • List benefits of smartphones in construction
    • Describe the drawbacks of smartphones in construction
    • Explain why effective communication is important
    • List different types of IoT onsite
    • Discuss some people's passion for the field
    • Describe some uses for drones onsite
    • Explain why this field is just at the beginning

  • Smartphones in Construction Safety


  • Smartphones are everywhere and there are millions of apps for them. 

    How many Construction Safety Apps are there? Not many. 
    How many Risk Assessment Apps are there? Not many. 

    The field of Construct-Tech is just getting off the ground. It's time to take your part in it.

    It would be amazing if we could use our smartphones to make our work life easier, using less paper, getting the information to the right people faster and increasing productivity.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The Future of Safety - The Internet of Things

  • So what does the future hold? The future is not yet written. Maybe you have an invention in safety that can help prevent accidents and help save lives. 

    If you do have an idea, there are many ways of funding it. It's really a topic for another course, but we fully encourage you to be creative and invent the future of safety.
  • Here's an article to get you thinking about the future of safety.
    https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimvinoski/2019/02/13/ibm-watson-announces-partnerships-to-improve-worker-safety-through-watson-iot/#14496bf35a8e
  • Just like all the inventions that we have today came from a need, so too will the inventions of the future in safety. The hardhat came about to lower the incidence of head injuries on construction sites. The bright yellow or orange safety vest came about to create more visibility for construction site works and for us on the road when we have a flat tire. The tower crane came about with the need to move large objects around a construction site. 

    What idea do you have to make construction faster, better and safer?

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are the following:
    • A good construction app has a number of characteristics, including; language, intuitiveness, organized information, contains verbal instructions, is information secure and in line with privacy regulations.
    • Smartphones have their drawbacks as they reduce a person's concentration while working.
    • Smartphone communication should be short and effective.
    • There are many smartphone apps which can assist sites to be safer
    • Drones have many potential uses onsite
    • People's passion brings them to doing excellence at work.
    • IoT is just at the beginning of finding its uses onsite
    • Invention comes from a defined need
    • Think about how you can contribute to new technologies to make construction sites safer 
    • Smartphones have the potential to make construction more efficient.
